content.description:
Wenceslaus Hollar, Czech artist working in the Spanish Netherlands, Allegory of the Peace of Westphalia, engraving, 1648

Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Wellington, New Zealand Gift of Bishop Monrad, 1869/Bridgeman Images

Two female figures representing peace and plenty look into a mirror held by an angel. The woman in armor next to the mirror represents Bellona, the Roman goddess of war and victory. Figures representing war lie prostrate in the foreground.

The text below reads: “Thus Peace sends forth her horn of plenty, her favors through the [Holy Roman] Empire, Spain, and France. The kings stand united, and the people are obedient under you, o great Philip [Philip IV, King of Spain], and your flourishing race. Soon war will perish and the former age will shake off all evils, and give way to a golden age.”
content.question: The artist’s statement that the kings of France, Spain, and the Holy Roman Empire “stand united” most clearly suggests that

choices.label: he hoped the Peace of Westphalia would bring the rival Catholic powers back together
he wanted dynastic conflicts between the Habsburgs and rival royal houses to resume
he saw all of the major European powers as collapsing under the strain of the conflict
he thought rulers of Europe needed to stand together against the expanding Ottoman Empire

content.answer: he hoped the Peace of Westphalia would bring the rival Catholic powers back together
